p1.description: You changed the antibiotic attack site, and it cannot affect your function as a bacteria anymore.
You developed the ability to pump out the antibiotic before it can harm you.
Nearly all types of bacteria have become stronger and less responsive to antibiotic treatment.
Untreated, bacterial infections can spread rapidly. At this time the course of medicine has been effective. Bad luck.
The term 'antibiotic' originally referred to a natural compound produced by a fungus or another microorganism. You have been treated.
You have become stronger after being treated with a different kind of drugs.
You have acquired pieces of DNA that code for the resistance properties from other bacteria; therefore you are stronger now.
You have thrived in an unclean environment. Happy days!
Antibiotics insert in a food chain can cause resistance in bacteria.
You have infected a source of drinkable water, affecting a whole village. Well done!
A doctor prevented a wrong diagnosis. You have been killed.
A washed apple prevented you from spreading.
SNAPPs have successfully treated superbugs infections and could become a possible replacement for antibiotics.
You have been subjected to restricted antibiotic policies, making it hard for your spreading. Bad days!
Probiotics are a likely good source for fighting bacteria. You have been killed.

p2.description: Your flu infection has been treated with antibiotics. Bad luck!
You have skipped a dose of your treatment. Bad luck!
You have correctly discarded any leftover medicine once completed your treatment.
Antibacterial-containing products have not been proven to prevent the spread of any infection. Think twice before using it.
You took antibiotics to treat a viral infection.
Mr Fleming has discovered the first antibiotic, the penicillin, in 1927.
You have good hygiene habits. It helps prevent and spread of infections.
Regular soap and water are enough to clean your hands and limit the spread of bacteria.
Antibiotics insert in a food chain can cause resistance in bacteria.
You are in good shape! Eating nutritious food, getting enough sleep and exercise, and avoiding stress all help to have an excellent immune system.
You took someone else's antibiotics. It has no effects on your infection, and it can cause harmful side effects.
A common misconception is that a person's body becomes resistant to specific drugs. You need to check your facts.
You have covered the broken skin with a clean bandage to prevent bacteria from spreading. Well done.
You have heated your food at the right temperature before eating, +70C degrees kills dormant bacteria.
While travelling, you have eaten from a street food stool. Bad hygiene practices can lead to bacterial infection.
After feeling better, you have not stopped your treatment. Well done!
